meta_data.title: Chris has a book out! Sex and Marriage, Unlocking and Restoring the Power of Sex through Biblical and Psychological Insight | Let’s Talk About It

transcription_data.text: Welcome to Reconstructed Faith, a podcast where we talk about truth you can build your life on. We hope to dive into the hard conversations of life and faith and seek out reasonable, substantive answers. My name is Colson Lechner, and I'm joined by Chris Legg and Bryn Starnes. This is Reconstructed Faith. Welcome back to the Reconstructed Faith podcast. My name is Colson Lechner joined in studio by my partners in crime, Bryn Starnes and Chris Legg. Hey guys. Hey. Today we are, we have some exciting things to talk about. I'm excited because Chris, it's been a long time coming and it's been published now for how long? Oh man, you've got me on the spot. So premises is that we need to deconstruct our faith regularly and consistently be reconstructing our faith. I think of that as just another way to describe growth, for example. So, so I would, one of the ways as a counselor, where I've seen this be an issue in the church and in Christianity has to do with marriage and in particular sex. And so if it doesn't have that, if that is a disadvantage, then now all of a sudden marriage is disadvantaged versus all other friendships. So yeah, just an additional thought. Wonderful. undertone of transaction of this for that. And so. How do you think that happened? Like we don't have
to unpack fully, but how do you, why do you think that's so prevalent? Like, why do you think so many
marriage books? Well, is it because that sells? Is it because it's like the practicality of
who we are as humans that we, we're so used to transactions or is it just conditions?
It's all, I mean, I also wonder if it's, no one has, I don't know, is it like a lack of pairing
of psychology with the, like a solid theology? That could be, I think, I think there's, there's
some great marriage books out there that are theologically based, like the Chan's recent one
is really good or some of the older ones. And then you've got these, you know, back in the 70s,
you had essentially like, like medical doctors or who wrote books on sex for marriage. Dr. Ed Weets,
which you read it and it's like, that's not the act of, maybe it's the act of marriage anyway,
but is, I mean, it's like reading a book about plumbing is what it's about, which,
which understand in the 70s, a lot of Christians didn't have because sex ed was still often fought
by Christians because they didn't want the school teaching it. They didn't want the school teaching
it, but they weren't teaching it. And so when, when neither one is happening, you end up with
these very messed up perspectives. And so a lot of kids were just getting nothing. And, and so then
you get, I mean, literally you would get, you're doing premarital counseling, you would get handed
this book by a couple of medical professionals about, and it's literally called the act of
marriage. I mean, that's like, it sounds like laying pipe. Like it's, it's even that feel and
they, they were ahead of their time and their book got recommended to lots of people, but it still
was very much so the, the level of what we understand and don't understand about sex,
what we're willing to talk about and not willing to talk about about sex. And especially for women,
this weird combination of like, you're supposed to be this hyper prudish, you know, in all areas of
your life. And then you get married and then you're suddenly supposed to somehow be like,
well, a prostitute who cleans house to quote that client. It's like, that's, that's a harsh left
turn. I mean, that's such a juxtaposition and it's, and it creates, and we've talked about
very often in the church, unfortunately, and I think we have a long heritage of sex being
treated as like a tolerated sin. That goes way back into Roman Catholic doctrine that, that,
that God kind of tolerates sex because it procreates. And, and that's, that's why, you know,
priests don't want to be married because then they would have sex and then that would be bad. And,
and, and so they would be tainted by married sex. And, and, and they use passages like David talking
about in sin, I was conceived and saying like, Oh, see, because even David's, when David's parents
who were married had sex, that was sin. And anyway, just, it was just a misunderstanding of scripture
across the board. And it was so badly done. And it wasn't until a few hundred years ago,
even as I understand it, that the Catholic church accepted that the original sin, the concept of,
of Eve eating the fruit wasn't just a euphemism for sex, that the original sin was Adam and Eve
having sex. Oh my gosh. And so that's just obviously, that's not right. I mean, the exact
opposite is the picture in the garden of that these, these couple was naked and they were
unashamed. Like there was nothing withheld in regards to that. They were for each other
physically and emotionally and spiritually. They were made specifically to fulfill that with each
other. And then sin is what marred that. Right. And, and, and so to reclaim, you know, naked and
unashamed as to reclaim the garden, not somehow to mess up. Like that's the goal is to get back to
having a single person, a covenant relationship where you're saying like, Hey, you and me forever,
which I think is maybe the title of Chan's book, by the way, it's something close to that. Wow.
It is. And so it's a great, it's a, it's that picture of, this is what God intended.
And I think it's there, but we, most of us have come out of being taught at a certain way. And,
and so I feel like it's been totally inappropriate and we've seen a pushback. Now, sometimes we see
that overdone today and there's some Christian authors who are coming out and they're kind of
going with a, you know, a torched earth policy about this or a nuclear policy with it. That's
not right either. So about a lot of things. So like anything that's been miss, mistaught instead
of centering back to scripture, they just go to the other extreme. Well, then some other,
like the other side, that's also not biblical. Right. Exactly. Yeah. Well, that's the, so you've
heard, y'all have probably heard me say, I know, Bryn, you have, because you've heard me see,
teach it to the youth, but that, that the idea of sex as sacred is the biblical picture.
That sex is special. It's sacred. It's a beautiful thing in its place. And it's destructive outside
of that, just like the work in the tabernacle that, you know, you, in its place, these things
are incredible. I mean, they're connections to God and yet outside of their place, they're
lethal. Right. Right. And so in the same way, we run into that with, in regards to sex. Well,
what happened was, you know, in the mid 1900s, the world began to come out and say like, no,
sex isn't special. It's common. And so all different, all different types of philosophies
kind of came together and said that like sex is common. It's not, it's not, everyone does it.
Right. And, and I know you, your parents pretended like they didn't do it, but they did. And so did
their parents and so did their parents and they did it with everybody. And everybody has sex all
the time. And anyone says otherwise is lying. And it's just this, you know, this history that goes
back. And, and, and so the truth is everybody just does this and it's all the time. And there's
nothing special about it at all. It's just common birds do it. Bees do it, you know, cattle does it.
Everybody does it. Humans do it. And the Christian immediate knee jerk response was to say, no,
it's not common. It's trash. Yeah. And, and so stay away from that. That's trashy and it's bad.
And, and, you know, all, et cetera, et cetera. And that, that was the wrong response. It just was the
right response was to stick to scripture. No, sex is sacred. You can't, as a understanding common,
you can never understand the great power of sex, understanding it is common.
I just got to take to a group of students about this. And so I, I intentionally portrayed this
to them in the worst possible light, like, okay, so you're as hot as you're going to get right now.
You're in your mid twenties, right? I mean, it's on the erotic playing field. No one's getting much
better than this probably. Right. Yeah, exactly. Like enjoy it, boys and girls, because you're
going to start the downward path soon. They're all, they all went and bought retinol after you
sold them. So it's just going to, that's the nature of when it comes to eroticism and, and you're
going to marry somebody because you know, you're good Christian kids and you're going to marry
somebody or commit to them. And sex is going to be super novel because you've never had sex or
not much sex before. And, and you're, so you're going to be at the height of your erotic playing
height of your erotic playing abilities, right? You're going to be the best looking you're
probably ever going to be your whole life when you get married and sex is now new and novel.
And so you're going to have sex a bunch and then slowly over the next decades,
you're going to get lose erotic power because you're going to become less than you're going
to turn less and less heads as you get older, probably. And, and the world's going to keep
telling you that's all that's valuable about you. Right. And then you're going to be having sex with
somebody who you've already had sex with several hundred times, if not now several thousand times.
Right. So have fun kids. Like that's how I presented it. And I was like, there you go.
And they're like looking all bleak. And I was like, what if though, God offers something
better than novel and better than erotic? And by the way, kiss illicit goodbye,
because that's still a sin and you almost can't do that with your spouse. It's like,
so the heat of illicit sexuality of hidden secretive, dark sexuality, abusive, hurtful
sexuality, that that's gone. And now erotic sexuality is becomes a fruit that rarely,
it's not the constant production. So, you know, what have you got? And that's actually,
we talked about in the book is there, God offers a third option, which is intimate sexuality,
which is what is it like to be chosen sexually when someone actually knows you
and they don't just know your, your body. And that's awesome. It's awesome when someone knows
every inch of your body and they want to make that body feel good, but also they know every
inch, they know you, they're your heart and your soul and your mind, and they're still wanting to
go to bed with you. Like that's really being chosen. And so with that, that just grows.
And again, the research backs this couples who work hard to have a good marriage, often report
higher satisfaction rates, even about sex after 30 years, 40 years, 50 years of marriage,
then they did as honeymooners. The world would be like, what? What? That makes no sense. You're
right. Unless there's something better than you throw all of the best you've got against the wall
and still people who've been married 40 years are happier. Now, not all of them, because a lot of
them have, they live in these dead marriages and they have for 30 years at that point. And now,
now you've got marriages that are ending two years into the marriage. They're sexless because of
addictions and stuff like that. But anyway, that's the principle of the book is how do we create such
an awesome marriage that our kids are inspired. We're inspired. Husbands and wives are inspired
by each other in their faith and to continue to grow that. And again, it's an answer that as so
far as I can tell, by the way, only God offers. No one else is offering intimacy as the solution
to the loss of novelty, to the loss of eroticism, which are given things. Everybody else is killing
themselves and slicing up their bodies, trying to maintain their eroticism or whatever. And it's
crazy making. Or you could have someone choose you even when you're old and gray and wrinkled.
It does not require Christianity to have that, but it requires a vision bigger than anything
the world has to offer to have that. So I love it. I think it's a beautiful picture. And
I love that Ginger and I have now had several people reach out to us and say,
based on y'all's marriage, we want you to do our premarital counseling. We want you to talk
through with us. It's like the highest compliment for marriage. Oh my gosh, so awesome. And it's
kind of weird now I'm at that age where I'm publishing a book and the old Christian marriage
books always had a picture of the couple on the back and you would like 20 or 30 years,
it does not age well. Yeah, not at all. The dude in the polyester suit with his wife with the big
hair, you know, hive, beehive hair. And you're like, I don't want to think about them having sex.
Stop putting that on the cover of the like. So anyway, we intentionally didn't do that.
But that's why we went with a very tame picture of a door in a garden.
Yes. Those are two of the analogies we use in the book. So okay, I want that to be the case.
And here's what makes you so if any of you out there who are deconstructors understand if you're
deconstructing largely because of the way your parents taught or because of your parents' marriage
or the way you were taught about sex and marriage and now you've begun to think, wait,
I don't get to be a free moral agent in regards to sex in my marriage if I'm a Christian, understand,
that's not the teaching of Christianity. That's not what Christ was trying to teach.
And so as it's so often the case, we're actually deconstructing either people,
which we always highly recommend, or you're deconstructing faith in a God who doesn't exist
in a series of truth claims that are wrong. And we need to always deconstruct those.
Yeah. And that's my opinion.
Yeah. And I mean, I would just add to that. Like from my perspective, I think sometimes
there are ways in which what we've been taught Mars, our view of God, and we don't realize that
until those start being brought to light. And so this is totally one of those in my mind of,
like, there may be couples out there who think their marriage is fine, you know, may even have
a misunderstanding of some of these things that have happened for, have been an understanding for
so long that they don't realize it. And yet it's affecting your view of God. And so, and his, like,
what he's asking of you and what he's provided for you and what the, like we said earlier,
what the picture of Christ in the church even is. And so even if you wouldn't consider yourself
currently deconstructing, I think digging into healthy theology on something like sex and marriage,
whether or not you're married, I think can always help you draw closer to the Lord and,
and even correct views of him that, that you may not realize are harming you,
if that makes sense. So yeah, just an additional thought.
Wonderful. Well, if you're looking for it on Amazon, the book is Sex and Marriage,
Unlocking and Restoring the Power of Sex through Biblical and Psychological Insight.
Chris, thanks for taking time to talk about this. I know you're not big on kind of self-promotion.
I'm so bad at it. Colson and I are telling you, go buy the book.
I need to be better. I really do. But, but I think it, it can be really beneficial. So thanks guys.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith.
If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave us a review.
It'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed,
shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South
Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
